text:
Given two time series, `x` and `y`, how does `lag` work?

Does it compare `x[i+lag]` to `y[i]` or `x[i]` to `y[i+lag]`  or something else?

```help?> crosscor
search: crosscor crosscor! crosscov crosscov!

  crosscor(x, y, [lags]; demean=true)

  Compute the cross correlation between real-valued vectors or matrices x and y, optionally specifying the lags.
  demean specifies whether the respective means of x and y should be subtracted from them before computing their cross
  correlation.

  If both x and y are vectors, return a vector of the same length as lags. Otherwise, compute cross covariances
  between each pairs of columns in x and y.

  When left unspecified, the lags used are the integers from -min(size(x,1)-1, 10*log10(size(x,1))) to min(size(x,1),
  10*log10(size(x,1))).

  The output is normalized by sqrt(var(x)*var(y)). See crosscov for the unnormalized form.```

elements.text:
help?> crosscor
search: crosscor crosscor! crosscov crosscov!

  crosscor(x, y, [lags]; demean=true)

  Compute the cross correlation between real-valued vectors or matrices x and y, optionally specifying the lags.
  demean specifies whether the respective means of x and y should be subtracted from them before computing their cross
  correlation.

  If both x and y are vectors, return a vector of the same length as lags. Otherwise, compute cross covariances
  between each pairs of columns in x and y.

  When left unspecified, the lags used are the integers from -min(size(x,1)-1, 10*log10(size(x,1))) to min(size(x,1),
  10*log10(size(x,1))).

  The output is normalized by sqrt(var(x)*var(y)). See crosscov for the unnormalized form.

text: I got it, but I'm confused why StatsBase.jl docs refer to Statistics.jl :thinking_face:

elements.text: I got it, but I'm confused why StatsBase.jl docs refer to Statistics.jl

text:
I started with StatsBase, but then removed it and added Statistics (thinking StatsBase is a part of Statistics), but now I can't use the StatsBase methods :thinking_face:

Are these really two separate libraries? How is this supposed to work?

elements.text: I started with StatsBase, but then removed it and added Statistics (thinking StatsBase is a part of Statistics), but now I can't use the StatsBase methods
Are these really two separate libraries? How is this supposed to work?

text: I see. StatsBase.jl depends on Statistics.jl, but it does not re-export so do people usually import both?

elements.text: I see. StatsBase.jl depends on Statistics.jl, but it does not re-export so do people usually import both?

text: The answer is yes they are two separate libraries and yes people (at least me) Import both. Actually often all three, if you also throw StatsFuns into the mix... There is a longstanding stalled PR trying to integrate things somewhere I believe

text: Hmm. Yeah. Seems less than ideal. Thanks.
